Rockwell has generously contributed ten thousand dollars to this neighborhood's schools, clinics and youth centers! Granting a restraining order on the construction site will throw hundreds of Philadelphians out of work, and will lend validation to this contemptible and groundless nuisance suit, which speaks directly to the kind of greed and treachery that today is threatening the very fabric of our society.

dialogues.text: Faith, Andy, is the belief in something for which we have no evidence. It doesn't apply to this situation. (slapping his shoulder) Go home. I mean, get back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving the fax a quick scan) Thanks, Bruno. (to Alan and Chandra) I've been out of the office four days. I don't want them to think I've been to the beach. (searching for something) Okay. Check this out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew puts on a pair of big glasses with tortoise shell frames, meant to help conceal the blotches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hides everything, right? What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who you look like, Andy? That actor, in that movie. Not the one where he was autistic, the one where he dressed up like a lady on a soap opera...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.text: (clearly in pain) Excuse me a sec...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like my cousin Fredo.

dialogues.text: CAMERA HOLDS ON Chandra, Alan and Bruno. SOUND OF BATHROO slamming shut. Bruno saunters across the room and knocks on the bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay, Andy?

dialogues.text: Andrew rests his head against the wall, sweat covering hi face. A storm of fire has passed through him, and he's ho it's over for now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, you guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Thanks, guys.

dialogues.text: Miguel puts his arms around Andrew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gillman's out of her office today. I told her to take a day off, and she did, can you believe it? Did you get someone to cover your class?

dialogues.text: Miguel touches Andrew's face, checking for fever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. They took blood? A specimen?

dialogues.text: Andrew holds an empty specimen cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you giving an exam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel places a gentle kiss on Andrew's sweaty forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a fever, baby.

dialogues.text: Suddenly, the facade cracks and TEARS STING Andrew's eyes

dialogues.text: I almost didn't make it to the bathroom, Miguel. I almost lost control right in front of everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding him) So what? It's nothing to be ashamed of. You have nothing to be ashamed of, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew pulls himself together, brushing aside tears, in control of his emotions once more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, here's my guy... Hey!

dialogues.text: Andrew catches the attention of a harried INTERN, whose surgeon's greens are covered with blood.

dialogues.text: Mr. Beckett, I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About my blood work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're waiting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... meanwhile, I'd like to prepare you for a colonoscopy, so we can take a look inside.

dialogues.text: Sounds delightful.

dialogues.text: Why do you need to do this?

dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you? Doctor... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my partner. We keep records of hospital visits. Nothing personal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Klenstein. (to Andrew) It's not a pleasant procedure, but if the KS is causing the diarrhea, we ought to know right away.

dialogues.text: It could be parasites, an infection...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A reaction to AZT...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's possible, but.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not going through some painful procedure until we've cancelled out everything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to help your "partner." You're not a member of his immediate family, I could have you removed from the ER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Intern) He's upset, he's sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't apologize for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not sorry, okay, fine. (the diplomat) Why don't we see what we find out from the blood work? I'll work on getting a specimen, I'm sure hospital food could help in that direction. Maybe, by then, we'll hear from my doctor, and we'll go from there. Okay? Everybody happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allright. I'll get on the lab about the blood work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Intern) I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The INTERN walks away. Andrew's BEEPER BEEPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the third time. I better call the office. (smiling at Niguel) Would you relax, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am relaxed.

dialogues.text: Andrew HOBBLES toward a pay phone, outside a VISITOR LOUN where weary relatives are watching TV. Andrew drops a quarter into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "If you or someone you know..."

dialogues.text: ANDREW'S POV ON TELEVISION: Joe Miller on the screen, wit words "Negligence... Malpractice... Auto accidents"... an the background, PHOTOS of MAIMED, BURNED, INJURED CLIENTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... has been injured through the fault of others, you may be entitled to legal remedy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: (INT/DAY), GRABS THE PHONE when Andrew's intercom BUZZES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frantic) Andy?! This is a disaster! We can't find your revisions on the Kronos complaint!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow down, Jamey, for Christ's sake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went down to Word Processing to pick up the corrected copy, but they said you haven't delivered the corrections. I told them you've been working on it at home, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew forgets his physical pain, this is more important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought it in last night, around midnight. It's in my computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you file it under?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamey puts his hands on Andrew's computer keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: K-R-O-one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamey types the file name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamey, I don't have to mention, do I, that we're up against a statute of limitations on this complaint which runs out in... (checks his watch) Seventy-five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamey stares dumbfounded at the computer monitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not here, Andy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew closes his eyes. He can't believe this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go down to Word Processing and tell those motherfuckers they better come up with that complaint, now! Or they are fucking dead! You tell them that comes from me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew SLAMS the phone into its cradle. He pauses, takes a deep breath, and says to himself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every problem has a solution. Every problem... has... a... solution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calmer, Andrew returns to the gurney, putting on his shir

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every problem has a solution...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel approaches with tea purchased at the canteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you getting dressed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to like this. Please try to smile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew puts his arms around Miguel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for leaving school, and coming here, and... (pulling back, putting on his jacket) I will be back. An hour, tops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to the office?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not smiling.

dialogues.text: Andrew rushes toward the exit doors.

dialogues.text: You're leaving the hospital? You're going into the office looking like that? Are you insane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hour!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drew!

dialogues.text: I promise!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Get down to Word Processing. Help Jamey look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: No, goddammit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Seidman is struck by the mess in the office, and Andrew's disheveled appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.text: I don't know what to do, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in God's name... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob...

dialogues.text: What's wrong with your face?

dialogues.text: What's wrong with my face? You want to know what's wrong with my face? I've got a skin condition. Next question, Bob? No more questions? Fine. Now can you help me find the complaint?

dialogues.text: Allright. Calm down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry...

dialogues.text: Seidman sits in front of Andy's computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was the file name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: K-R-O-one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you mistyped the name when you were saving it. We'll try combinations of those letters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seidman goes to work. Andrew leans over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, I probably just misfiled...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy?

dialogues.text: Walter Kenton is standing at Andrew's door. His demeanor casual. So casual it seems a little forced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some sort of problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Walter. Yeah. Some sort of major problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Congratulations! How is Lisa?! When can we see the baby?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have AIDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe WITHDRAWS his hand, before it touches Andrew's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa-oh! (beat) Sorry, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. Can I sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew hesitates. Joe doesn't sound sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew sits, Joe returns to his desk. (Joe finds himself acutely aware of where Andrew places his hands.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the cigars) New baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One week old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little baby girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids are great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Beckett. I'm real excited about it. (glances at his watch) What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was fired by Wyant Wheeler. I plan to bring a wrongful termination suit against Charles Wheeler and his partners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to sue Wyant Wheeler Hellerman Tetlow and Brown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct. I'm seeking representation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I misplaced an important complaint. That's their story. Want to hear mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many lawyers did you go to, before you called me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was diagnosed with AIDS eight months ago. During a bout of pneumonia. I recovered quickly and was back at work in ten days. Since I was doing so well on the AZT, we decided against telling anyone about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lover and I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your... lover?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel Alvarez. We've lived together for nine years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dove back into work, everything was fine. Until the lesions started...

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON ANDREW WAUKING THROUGH THE LOBBY OF THE WHEELER
dialogues.text: Building (INT./DAY). He's wearing MAKEUP, which sort of covers the blotches. (NOTE: PICTURE and ANDREW'S VOICE OV do NOT match up. This is no ordinary flashback) ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First on my leg. Then my forearm, my back. Then... my face. For a short period, I avoided the office during the day, waiting for the chemo therapy to clear up the lesions...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I never let anything slide. I made all my calls from home. I worked sixteen hour days on a complaint for a 350 million dollar copyright infringement suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the day the complaint was due, it disappeared. Erased from my computer. I thought I was losing it, mentally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That can happen, it's called AIDS dementia when it gets into your brain. But miraculously, a copy of the complaint was located at the last minute, and we got it to court on time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning, I was called to the office for a meeting with the managing partners. Walking down that corridor was strange. Felt like everyone was staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, they are staring. What's that shit on your face?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makeup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The partners were waiting for me in the main conference room.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA TRACKS INTO THE CONFERENCE ROOM, GIVING US ANDREW'
dialogues.text: POV as he enters the room where Wheeler, Kenton, Killcoyn Bob Seidman are waiting (INT./DAY) ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, Andy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheeler's secretary, LYDIA, takes notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob Seidman CANNOT look directly at Andrew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy. Before we begin, I'd just like to say: everyone in this room is your friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (NOTE: Joe IS SEEN IN HIS OFFICE, or LEANING AGAINST A WINDOW IN THE CONFERENCE ROOM whenever he speaks.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More than your friend. Family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles, I must apologize again, for the Kronos mishap. (smiling) It was a scary few minutes around here. Wow. But thank God, the complaint was found. And no damage was done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time. What about next time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There won't be a next time, I guarantee it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy. It seems that something has come over you, lately: A kind of... stupor, a fogginess, a lack of focus... Earth to Andy. Anybody home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helloooo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Andy. The last four, five months you've seemed really out of it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least... different, somehow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (keeping it positive) Perhaps... you're right. I've certainly been busy. With the Kronos complaint, a preliminary injunction hearing and the Saunders trial all falling at the same time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some people think you have an attitude problem, Beckett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Who thinks that, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheeler seems very grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no idea there was a concern in that area. Hey: (a smile) I'll get to work on it right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO ONE else smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been talking it over, Andy. Your future that is... We feel that, because we respect you so much, we have to be honest with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honesty is always best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really think so, Andy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Bob, I do. (to the group) Excuse me? Am I being fired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's put it this way, Andy: your place in the future of this firm is no longer secure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a word, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't think it's fair to keep you here, where your future is limited. But we wish you luck, Andy, all the luck in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheeler rises, wearing a friendly smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I hate to rush you out of here, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's got lots of other people's lives to ruin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... we've got a committee meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Charles. With all due respect... this is... preposterous! It doesn't make any sense, it sounds as if we're talking about someone else. Pardon the lack of humility, but I've had the distinct impression I was kind of... one of the rising stars around here. And I feel that wasn't just my imagination. And I also think I deserve to know what's really going on here, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're right, Beckett, you don't have an attitude problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd lost confidence in me, why did you give me the Kronos suit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hoped the challenge would improve your performance. You could say it was a carrot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A carrot?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I buy that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As in, the vegetable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly emotional) Andy, you nearly blew the case, for God's sake! That alone is inexcusable. It would have been catastrophic for us. Put yourself in our shoes, Andy. There's no coming back from an error like that, regardless of who you are! (softer) I'm sorry, Andy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew FREEZES -- the full nature of this situation hitti home. He looks each of the PARTNERS in the eye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh... Okay... I see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... at last LOOKING DIRECTLY AT Wheeler's secretary Lydia whose pen is poised above her notebook, waiting for someo to say something. Wheeler breaks the silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, Andy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheeler, Kenton, Killcoyne, Seidman and Lydia file out. Andrew doesn't move. A SECURITY GUARD enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here to escort you to your office so you can organize your belongings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Explain to me like I'm a two year old, because there's an element to this I can't get through my thick head: Didn't you have an obligation to inform your employer you had this dreaded, deadly, infectious disease?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew removes his ballcap -- his hair is cut short, to disguise the effects of chemo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The law says people with disabilities cannot be terminated, so long as they can perform the duties required by their position...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay... They discover you have this horrible, disgusting, terminal illness, and they panic, for any number of perfectly valid reasons. They're frightened for themselves, their families... Maybe it's the homo angle. Maybe they don't want to rub elbows with someone who's just popped out of the closet with a terminal case of acne. And how do they explain your status to the client for Chrissake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, from the day I arrived to the day they fired me, I performed consistently, thoroughly and with absolute excellence. And if they hadn't fired me, that's what I'd be doing today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... They want you out. It's against the law to fire you for having AIDS, so they make you look like a fuck up. Which leads us to the mysterious, lost file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sabotaged me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you were going to say that. I don't buy it, and I don't see a case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. I know I have a case. If you don't want to take it for personal reasons...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct. I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew rises, thoroughly business-like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beckett? I'm sorry about... what's happened to you. It's a fucking kick in the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a smile) Don't send flowers, Joe. I'm not dead yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still uncomfortable, as Andrew's leaving) Have a nice day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew nods, passing one of Joe's colleagues, a hustler named FILKO, who STARES SHAMELESSLY. Joe approaches Iris's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find out if Armbruster can see me this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still staring) What the hell's wrong with him?

dialogues.speaker: THE STREET
dialogues.text: (EXT./DAY). CLOSE ON ANDREW, standing there as an endless people passes by. He watches them go, thinking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had contact with someone who has AIDS, and you're worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not worried. What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sits in his shirtsleeves on the examining table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checking your blood pressure, relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOCTOR wraps the blood pressure unit around Joe's arm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't have contact. What do you consider "contact?" We were sitting in the same room, three, four feet... What if you shake hands? Wait. I know the answer. Only sex, or sharing needles. I know that. We didn't shake hands, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Armbruster squeezes the blood pressure pump,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HIV virus can only be transmitted through the exchange of bodily fluids, namely blood and semen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe begins rolling down his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but Doc, isn't it true they keep finding out new things about this disease? So you tell me, today, there's no danger, and I go home, and I hold my baby, and six months from now I hear on the news: "whoops! We were wrong.' You can carry it on your clothes, your skin, and now I've got to worry about my kid. What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Armbruster has been preparing a syringe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to draw blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are we going to do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe. I don't care a whit about your private life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to give me an AIDS test?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe HOPS off the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy sat in my office! You can't get AIDS that way, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't travel through the air, by breathing, or touching, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not by touching, or shaking hands, or hugging, using the same toilet... Even kissing someone with AIDS is safe. But it there's something in your past you're worried about...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Doc, but I don't need an AIDS test. Are you crazy? But thanks for the information. Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe throws on his jacket, opens the door... then TURNS BA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my past?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IV drug use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A homosexual encounter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unprotected sex with a prostitute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking it over) Uh.... No. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or unprotected sex with someone you didn't know very well, any time during the last twelve years.

dialogues.speaker: A MOMENT.
dialogues.text: Joe returns to the examining table, and rolls up his slee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a problem with gays, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not especially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa eats standing up, at the stove, while Joe walks the BABY in their modern kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many gays do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Berman. Aunt Teresa. My cousin Tommy who lives in Rochester. Eddie Meyers from the office. Joe Cantwell, he's one of the partners. His lover, Greg. Stanley, the guy who's putting in our kitchen cabinets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment, Joe is struck dumb. Then he says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Aunt Teresa is gay? That beautiful, sensuous woman is a... lesbian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably since she was born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allright. I admit it: I'm prejudiced. I don't want to work with a homosexual. You got me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Joe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, two guys, doing the horizontal thing? I don't get it. Don't they get confused? "Is that mine? I thought it was yours." Hey, call me old fashioned, call me conservative... I think maybe you have to be a man to get just how nauseating the whole basic idea really is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the way they work out, pumping up, so they can be macho and faggot at the same time... I can't stand that shit. Now I'm being totally honest with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's perfectly clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you take a client if you were constantly thinking: "I hope this guy doesn't touch me. I don't even want him to breathe on me?"

dialogues.speaker: THE STREETS OF PHILLY ARE DUSTED WITH SNOW, STORE WINDOWS
dialogues.text: decorated for Christmas. Joe steps out of the Famous 4th St. Deli, with a package (EXT./DAY) ... TITLE: "Two weeks later."

dialogues.speaker: JOE SITS AT A TABLE IN THE PUBLIC LAW LIBRARY, SURROUNDED
dialogues.text: books and legal pads, hard at work. He's eating a pastram sandwich which he hides behind a reference book when a LI saunters by (INT./DAY) ... A CHAIR SQUEAKS and Joe LOOKS UP TO SEE: Andrew taking a seat across the room (the blotches have b reduced by chemo, but he's struggling with a cold). Andre removes notepads and pens from his briefcase. He takes ou package of tissues, blowing his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe slides to the far end of his table, stacking seven or eight HUGE REFERENCE BOOKS in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew opens a book, taking notes. Rubs his eyes. Writes something. Sneezes. A LIBRARIAN delivers a book to Andrew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the supplement. You're right, there is a section on... (lowers her voice) ... HIV related discrimination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew takes the book from her -- but she remains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a private research room available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew BLOWS HIS NOSE. Now other PATRONS are watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you be more comfortable in a research room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) No. But would it make you more comfortable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LIBRARIAN turns away, shrugging to a PATRON, indicati she's done all she can do. As Joe continues to watch: one of Andrew's NEIGHBORS pick up his books and moves away. Joe rises, gliding down an aisle of books, keeping one ey on Andrew, who concentrates on his work. Joe approaches, nonchalantly, as if he just happens to be sauntering by. Suddenly he "notices" Andrew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Beckett. How's it goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew goes back to his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd you get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find a lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a lawyer. How's your baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh. Great. She's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayisha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayisha. Very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew focuses on his work. Joe steps away. Joe comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did they find out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a second, then:) One of the partners spotted a lesion on my forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearby, a CHINESE PROFESSOR looks up, startled, when she hears the word "lesion."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew concentrates on his work once more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you get from one lawyer spotting a lesion, which could have been a bruise, to the partners deducing you had AIDS and basing a decision to terminate you on that conclusion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CHINESE PROFESSOR moves away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew removes a legal pad with "KENTON" written in big letters across the top, and lots of notes underneath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The partner who spotted the lesion, Walter Kenton, used to work for Benton, Myers, in D.C. There's a paralegal there, Maria Torres. She's had lesions on and off for three years. She says it was common knowledge around the office that her lesions were caused by AIDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't fire her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They didn't fire her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew goes back to his work. Joe stands there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Kenton connected the... lesion, and whatever suspicions he had about your personal life... to this woman, Maria... and blew the whistle on you. Suddenly you're losing files, and it's time to let you go. But, up to this point, you've been their Golden Boy, their rising star... Their behavior is... inconsistent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew goes back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no relevant precedent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up) Arline decision. Supreme Court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arline?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew SHOVES the legal book toward Joe. CLOSE ON ANDREW'S HANDS (with one blotch) on the book's w pages. The book is still facing Andrew. If Joe wants to read it, he'll have to turn it around. Joe looks at Andrew's hands. A MOMENT. Joe turns the book around, begins to read:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Federal Vocational Rehabilitation Act of 1973 prohibits discrimination..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... against otherwise qualified handicapped persons who are able to perform the duties required by their employment..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Although the ruling did not address the specific issue of HIV and AIDS discrimination..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DISSOLVE TO SAME ANGLE AN HOUR LATER: Andrew and Joe face other at their table, but NO ONE ELSE remains at that tab or at the table next to it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Subsequent decisions have held that AIDS is protected as a handicap under law, not only because of the physical limitations it imposes..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIGHT): Joe pacing, Andrew reading. Their section of the library is COMPLETELY EMPTY but for Andrew and Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "But because the prejudice surrounding AIDS exacts a social death which precedes the actual, physical one..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DISSOLVE TO SAME ANGLE, LATER: Andrew and Joe sit on the same side of the table, reading the same book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "This is the essence of discrimination: formulating opinions about others not based on their individual merits but, rather, on their membership in a group with assumed characteristics...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The library is QUIET. Andrew SNEEZES. Joe scoots his chair away from Andrew by eight inches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSCULAR, SWEATY MALE BODIES SLAMMING INTO EACH OTHER, so GRUNTS, skin SLAPPING against skin (INT./NIGHT) ... ... Hand SLAPPING a butt under satin shorts ... Sweaty armpits... the ROAR OF A CROWD... ... BASKETBALL PLAYERS embracing, twirling each other aro fiving... dialogues.speaker: Unknown

The lawy Ralph Lauren polos, chinos and ball caps. The place reeks cigar smoke. Walter Kenton has a twentyfive year old WIFE Charles Wheeler's nine year old GRANDSON sits nearby. Wheeler turns the GRANDSON'S ballcap around, smiling lovingly at the boy. JUST BEYOND WHEELER: The door to the box is opened by a S GUARD and a well-dressed, charismatic MAN looks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spotting him) Julius!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. J.!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen... Ladies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JULIUS ERVING enters, greeted by the LAWYERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it goin', Doctor?/This is an honor!/etc ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is opened again, by the SECURITY GUARD, REVEALIN Joe Miller (in jeans and basketball jacket) and a MARSHAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Charles Wheeler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheeler turns. Joe SLAPS a document into Wheeler's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Summons. For you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOW the box is QUIET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say. What's up, Chuck?

dialogues.speaker: THE BRIGHTLY LIT, RESTRICTED, INNER CORRIDOR OF SPECTRUM
dialogues.text: Stadium (INT./NIGHT) where Wheeler walks beside Bob Seidm with Walter Kenton and Kenneth Killcoyne just behind. SOU OF THE GAME STILL IN PROGRESS can be heard, but FAR AWAY. Occasionally the lawyers are passed by FOOD SERVICE or LA SERVICE EMPLOYEES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... interview every employee, support staff, associates, partners. Did any of them know Andy was sick? How did they know? Did he tell them? Did they notice something was wrong with his appearance? None of this information got to the managing partners. We know that. Make sure everyone else does too... And Beckett: I want to know everything about his personal life. Did he frequent those pathetic bars on Camac Street?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring Seidman) What about other homosexual facilities, whatever they are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What deviant groups or organizations did he secretly belong to? (with irritation) What is it, Bob?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's settle with Andy and put this whole tragic mess behind us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrive at a quiet, semi-private cul de sac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew brought AIDS into our offices, into our men's room. He brought AIDS to our annual goddamn family picnic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ought to be suing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Christ's sake, where's your compassion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Compassion? Andy sucks cocks, Bob. He takes it up the ass. He's a pervert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only Seidman shows any kind of REACTION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's kind of... extreme, Walt. Andy's private life is none of our business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob. You're trying my patience. Andrew Beckett is making his private life our business. We gave him Kronos. Did he say, "I'm sick. I might not be able to see this through?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was doing a great job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob. I must ask you to shut the fuck up. Did Andrew Beckett say "I might not be able to serve our clients to the best of my ability?" He said nothing. And now, Andrew Beckett proposes to haul me into a court of law, to sling accusations at me, in full view of the entire, Philadelphia, judicial establishment. My God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beckett doesn't want to go to court, he's hoping for a quick tasty settlement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A jury might decide that Andy has a case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. The man was fired for incompetence, not because he has AIDS. You didn't know he was sick, did you, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy Shit. Did you, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment) No. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheeler walks away, followed by Kenton and Killcoyne. Bob Seidman stands alone in this dark place. CITY SOUNDS ON A WORK DAY AS WE CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOB'S COLLEAGUE, FILKO, LOOKING DIRECTLY INTO CAMERA (in Joe's offices, INT./DAY):

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles Fucking Wyant Wheeler?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sweeps by, just arriving for work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Filko.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Filko keeps pace with Joe down the corridor. ANOTHER COLLEAGUE calls out from an office as Joe passes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's the local chapter of the ACLU!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a Republican, Joe! You belong to the NRA!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many toilet stalls are there in the women's restroom on this floor, Filko?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many... what?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Filko follows Joe into Joe's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two. How many toilet stalls are there in the men's room? Two, plus four urinals. How many wheelchair accessible toilets in either of those restrooms? Zero. In this entire building? Zero. Get the picture, Filko? Discrimination! You find yourself a female, paraplegic, legal assistant who is qualified to work here, except she can't take a leak... and you've got yourself a sex discrimination suit and a handicapped discrimination suit. Not handicapped. What do you call someone who can't use a normal restroom? "Gastro-intestinally challenged!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind Joe, out a large window: PAINTERS on a scaffold. Iris comes into the office and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wyant Wheeler's asking for a postponement on the prelim, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is dialing the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Low-life, sleazy scumbags. Of course they want a postponement, I've got a client with a terminal disease. They're going to drag their heels every step of the way, the rotten bastards. (tapping on the window, to the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that spelled right?

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR, JOE'S OFFICE BUILDING, WHERE PAINTERS ARE ADDIN
dialogues.text: question to the line of windows (DAY):

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Beckett. This is Miller.

dialogues.speaker: JOE'S VOICE COMES THROUGH, ON THE ANSWERING MACHINE IN
dialogues.text: Andrew and Miguel's loft (INT./DAY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to tell you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA DRIFTS THROUGH the loft, finding Andrew in the roo solarium, sitting crosslegged in front of a candle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... we're trying to set a date for the prelim. Hang in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew's eyes are closed. Next to him rests a tape player WOMAN'S VOICE IS HEARD, accompanied by NEW AGE MUSIC:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can heal myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can heal myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can heal myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can heal myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: each other in bed (INT./NIGHT) ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was coming out of the gym today, and I ran into Jimmy. Do you know what he asked me? "What's it like knowing your boyfriend's going to die?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerk... What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, "Everyone's going to die, Jimmy. But Drew's not going to die of AIDS. There's a cure around the corner, and he plans to be around to take advantage of it."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel strokes Andrew's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got that right, Mikey... (beat) You still believe that, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I think it will be a simple solution. They'll put it in a syringe, inject it into your bloodstream. It'll neutralize the virus. It'll revitalize the immune system, and people with AIDS will become healthy again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE: "Three months later."

dialogues.speaker: A LONG CORRIDOR IN A CITY COURT BUILDING
dialogues.text: corridor TWO FIGURES WALK TOWARD CAMERA (INT./DAY) ... The figures APPROACHING CAMERA are Andrew and Joe, steppi into and out of sunlight falling through tall windows. TITLE: "Pre-trial settlement conference."

dialogues.speaker: DOWN AN OPPOSITE CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: A PHALANX OF LAWYERS -- at least ten -- APPROACHING CAMER bulwark of white shirts and dark ties.

dialogues.speaker: ON ANDREW AND JOE
dialogues.text: Andrew's hair is short, but growing back, the blotches ha receded,his weight is up. He's in a stage of recovery.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE OTHER LAWYERS
dialogues.text: Charles Wheeler (seeming ironic) and Walter Kenton (he's pissed) lead the battalion. Behind them, walk young lawyers BELINDA CONINE and JEROME GREEN. Belinda is white, Jerome is black.

dialogues.speaker: HUSHED VOICES, (INT./DAY)
dialogues.text: A JUDGE'S CHAMBERS, with couches, soft chairs scattered i loose circle, like a casual living room. Joe and Andrew whisper to each other. The Wyant Wheeler t takes up several chairs. Belinda Conine and Jerome Green next to Wheeler and Kenton. Some of their ASSISTANTS stan Wheeler is looking across the room at... Andrew, who catches Wheeler's stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking better, Andy. How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SILENCE. Everyone watches Andrew for his reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, thanks, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDGE LUCAS GARNETT enters his chambers (not wearing a Judge's robe). He shakes hands with Wheeler and Kenton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles, Walter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations on the new grandson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. We're very happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge brushes by Joe and Andrew without a word. The r becomes SILENT as the Judge takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attorney for the plaintiff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph Miller, Your Honor. Macready and Shilts Legal Services.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen your television commercials. "If you or anyone you know has been injured through the fault of others... It should say, "through the negligence of others."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take that under consideration, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On behalf of the defendants?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belinda Conine. Of Petersen, Lehigh, Monroe and Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Jerome Green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a WASPISH lawyer wearing round glasses:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dexter Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A white-haired lawyer next to Belinda:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph Petersen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Joe) You're outnumbered four to one. (to the others) Whom do I address? I can't talk to four lawyers at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm chief litigator, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. I've asked the litigants to be present for this conference, in the hope we can settle this matter today, among ourselves... There is nothing I hate more, than to see lawyers suing each other. If you look at the opinion polls, when Mr. John Q. Citizen is asked to rank professions according to the respect he holds for them... Where are the lawyers? Somewhere below personal fitness trainers and only slightly above child pornographers. If we keep suing each other, if we fail to settle the smallest difference among ourselves with mutual respect, if we continue to scrap like bucks in heat, we'll fall lower on that list. And when people lose respect for lawyers, they lose respect for the law. And when this society loses all respect for the law, we'll be murdered in our beds, my friends, our cherished institutions will be burned to the ground and our children and our grandchildren will live like savages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it please Your Honor, we hope to settle this matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By God you will settle it! If you force this case to trial, young man, you'll regret it for the rest of your natural-born days... Now, Joseph. What would you require to settle this matter today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reinstatement at full salary. Back pay covering the period of unemployment and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it, Joe. (to Wheeler) He wants to come back to work, Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's impossible, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's impossible, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it please Your Honor, we're prepared to offer a cash settlement of twenty-five thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your generosity overwhelms me, Belinda, considering my client was earning over a hundred thou when he was terminated almost six months ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a break, Joe. Let's cut through these false attitudes. Give them a figure. How much do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to go back to work, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're here at my indulgence, young man. I'm waiting for a figure, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew and Joe confer with each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Based on what my client would have earned over the next three years, including benefits and projected raises, and the extraordinary cost of medical care for someone with Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome... We would settle today for the very fair amount of one million five hundred thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, Joe. Now, Belinda, I've got a figure over here, of one million, five. I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew WHISPERS to Joe, who interrupts the Judge:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more thing, Your Honor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jumping in) Any settlement agreement must include, and this is critical, a letter of exoneration, making clear my termination had nothing to do with the quality of my work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles Wheeler WHISPERS to Belinda Conine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, Mr. Beckett's incompetence nearly sabotaged a 350 million dollar suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was the one who was sabotaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have complaints about Mr. Beckett's lack of preparation, his disorganization, his arrogant, defensive attitude... The list goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why haven't you produced these letters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy. (to Wheeler) What's the big deal, Chuck? The boy wants a letter, to show to his mother, for her to keep after he's gone. Why are you being hard- assed about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could exonerate you, Andy. But I'd have to lie to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very calm) You can save it for the jury, Charles. I want to hear you say, under oath, in front of a judge and a jury, I'm a bad lawyer. (rises) Gentlemen. (to Belinda) Counselor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do this, Andy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa... (to Andrew) What do you expect them to say, you're Alan Dershowitz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trial takes time, Beckett. Do you know what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I catch your subtle drift, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew saunters out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be sorry, Beckett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy, you don't want this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe scans the room, all eyes are on him. His frown turns a grin. He faces the Judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all due respect, Your Honor, my client chooses to pursue his constitutionally guaranteed right to a trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonial house in Downington, Pennsylvania (EXT./DAY) ... Andrew walks toward the house, TALKING DIRECTLY TO CAMERA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the house where I grew up. In Downington, Pennsylvania. (pointing to the ground) See this... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA POINTS to SEVERAL PAIRS OF CHILD'S HAND PRINTS sidewalk, then, BACK TO ANDREW IN CLOSE UP, SMILING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are my cute little hand prints. And my brother's and my sister's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And today is... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today is my parents' fortieth wedding anniversary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew goes inside, speaking to the CAMERA:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the front door. I caught a finger in this door, once... (holds it up) This one. Broke it. (stepping inside) This is the hallway, my mother calls it a foyer...

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE HOUSE, (INT./DAY)
dialogues.text: CHILDREN are running through the house, while WOMEN sport corsages confer in the kitchen. A SIX YEAR OLD GIRL jumps Andrew's arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Andrew!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to CAMERA) This is my niece, Alexis. Say hello, Alexis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy's pregnant again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doing Walter Cronkite) You heard it here first, folks. News as it happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew's older and very down to earth sister JILL, puts h arms around Andrew, squeezing tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, darlin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my sister, Jill, the most fertile woman on the planet. She's married to Reverend Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel thin. (over Andrew's shoulder) Hello, Miguel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jill leaves Andrew's arms, the CAMERA IS TRADED OFF TO ANDREW, who SHOOTS JILL GIVING MIGUEL A HUG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jill. Nice to see you, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hugging Miguel) Handsome devil. (referring to Andrew) Is he eating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't discuss his weight. (to Andrew, behind CAMERA) Do we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what will we find in... da duh da duh da duh... the KITCHEN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GROUP OF LADIES SCREAM when CAMERA ENTERS KITCHEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There he is! Hi, Andrew! Don't point that thing at me! etc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew's mother Sarah wears an unpretentious flowery dres

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Mom. How do you feel on your fortieth anniversary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ancient. How do you think I feel? Put that thing down and give me a hug. (he keeps it pointed at her) Andrew, stop! ... He still doesn't listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's out in his shed showing your uncle his new riding mower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of Andrew's YOUNG NEPHEWS SHOVES HIS FACE into the CAMERA, UNTIL SCREEN GOES BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: QUIET, (INT./DAY)
dialogues.text: Andrew and his immediate family are gathered in the den, quietly, facing each other. Andrew's father, BUD, with an American flag pin in his lapel, sits next to Sarah. Jill the hand of her husband, REVEREND JIM. Two of Andrew's br MATT and RANDY, (big, athletic guys with mustaches) are t Andrew sits next to Miguel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things might be said, at the trial, that... are not going to be easy for you to hear. Things about me, about my private life. And I want to make sure it's okay with everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate you asking, Andy, but really, it's your call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think, Jill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be honest, I'm worried about Mommy and Daddy. They've had to go through so much already... And, we all know... (very difficult to say) There's going to be even worse things to deal with, eventually. I wonder if it's fair to put them through this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew's father STARES at his folded hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I know is, you got through your diagnosis fine, like a trooper. But when they fired you... you were so devastated, Andy... I don't expect any of my kids to sit in the back of the bus. Fight for your rights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mom... Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a pause before Bud Beckett speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Supposedly, the Lord doesn't give you more trouble than you can handle. But I'm having a hard time believing that these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew's construction worker brother, RANDY, wipes tears from his eyes. Clearly their father is in alot of pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy, the way you've faced this whole thing, you and Miguel, with so much courage... your mother and I have been so very impressed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew gazes at his father with incredible love. Miguel p an arm around Andrew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't imagine there is anything, that anyone could say, that would make us feel less proud of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (full of emotion) Thanks, Dad. I love you guys. How about you, Randy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. You're my kid brother, Andy. That's the bottom line. I mean, what are those bastards going to say? You're gay? Shit, I knew that when you were five years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone LAUGHS. Andrew and Randy high five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute... (to Andrew) You're gay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More laughter. But Jill speaks seriously:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you, Andy? You're not a militant type. You've always been so private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess... I don't have time for that any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim? Will you lead us in a prayer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone bows heads, holding hands in a circle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Lord. Sometimes it is difficult to remember to be grateful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To remember, in our times of sorrow and confusion, that we have You to turn to, and each other. Bless and keep Andrew and Miguel, dear Lord, deepen and strengthen their love as they face the struggles that lay ahead. Bless and watch over all of us, fill us with Your love, Your light, and Your peace, which passeth all understanding. In Jesus' name, we pray...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: BECKETTS' LIVINGROOM, SEEN THROUGH THE VIDEO CAMERA, (DAY)
dialogues.text: A local entertainer (GUIDO PAONESSA) launches into a standard, accompanied by a single guitar player, and Bud Sarah begin to dance, surrounded by family and friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "After all the days of Spring have flown..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIDEO CAMERA PANS: RELATIVES eating cake, KIDS chasing ea other, a GRANDMOTHER in a wheelchair holding a NEWBORN, watching silent, video home movies. CAMERA FINDS Andrew and Niguel eating anniversary cake (Andrew barely touches his). Playing for the camera, Migu dips his finger into icing and smears it onto Andrew's no Andrew tries to reach the icing with his tongue. CAMERA PANS WITH ANDREW as he comes forward to dance with mother, while Jill dances with their father. CAMERA RETURNS TO MIGUEL. MATT (behind the camera) says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Miguel, can you imagine any two people being together for forty years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZOOM IN CLOSE ON NIGUEL (who's watching Andrew):

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIDEO CAMERA PANS to Andrew dancing with his Mom, lingeri this IMAGE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget everything you've seen on TV, and in the movies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE: "Eight months later."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There won't be any last minute, surprise witnesses...

dialogues.speaker: A MAN LOOKING INTO CAMERA
dialogues.text: American, a Marine (INT./DAY) ... TITLE: "Opening statements." The MARINE is a JUROR. CAMERA PANS others: a BLACK LADY SCHOOLTEACHER, a POSTAL WORKER, an ASIAN COLLEGE STUDENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one will break down on the stand with a tearful confession...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are presented with a simple fact: Andrew Beckett was fired. You will hear two explanations for why he was fired. Ours. And theirs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe crosses the courtroom, coming to stand in front of... ANDREW, whose appearance has changed: thinner, paler than ever seen him, some blisters on his lips. But the most di thing about his appearance is the way he moves, slowly, l much older man. He's taking notes (which he will do relentlessly throughout the trial.) And he has a cane at side, which he'll use throughout the trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's up to you, to sift through layer and layer of truth, and determine for yourselves the version that sounds the most true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles Wheeler, Walter Kenton, Bob Seidman, Kenneth Kill sit BEHIND their lawyers, Belinda Conine and Jerome Green SEVERAL ASSISTANTS at the defense table. JUDGE GARNETT presides from his bench. Among the spectators, Miguel sits next to Sarah, and Andrew's sister Jill. AIDS ACTIVISTS in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are certain points in our version, that I must prove to you... Point number one: Andrew Beckett was... is a brilliant lawyer. A great lawyer. Point number two. Andrew Beckett, afflicted with a debilitating disease, made the legal, understandable, personal choice to keep the fact of his illness to himself... Point number three: His employers discovered his illness. And ladies and gentlemen, the illness I'm referring to, is AIDS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe pauses, letting that sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Point number four. They panicked. And, in their panic, they did what most of us would like to do with AIDS... Get it, and the people who have it, as far away from us as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe walks away from Andrew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The behavior of Andrew Beckett's employers may seem reasonable to you. It does to me. After all, AIDS is a deadly, incurable, disease...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But however you come to judge the behavior of Charles Wheeler and his partners in moral, ethical, human terms... When they fired Andrew Beckett because he had AIDS, they broke the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a swift, direct glance at the Judge, Joe speaks with considerable power and emotion:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: QUIET IN ANDREW'S CONDO, THE PARTY LONG OVER, (INT/NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Joe opens his briefcase, removing a legal pad with notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Miller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew clears away party debris from the table, making sp for his legal work. He is attached to an IV line, which i connected to a drip bag on a rolling stand, that can move with him. He is no longer in costume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You survived your first gay party intact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something, okay? When you're brought up, like the rest of us, in a place like where I was brought up, there's not a whole lot of discussion about... homosexuals. As a kid, you're taught right away that queers are weird, queers are funny, they're a danger to kids, they're afraid to fight, and they all want to cop your joint. And that pretty much sums up the general thinking out there, if you want to know the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for sharing that with me, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's review these notes for your testimony. We have a big day on Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe begins ticking off a list of courtroom reminders:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you refer to Wheeler, call him Charles, to show how you'd been admitted to the inner circle, you were considered one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted) Uh huh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beckett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles. Okay. Miller?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you... pray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe hesitates. They're having a personal conversation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe goes back to the notes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we establish how Wheeler's boys recruited you after law school...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you prayed for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a healthy baby. For Lisa to make it through the delivery. For the Phillies to get into the playoffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no self-pity) There's a possibility I won't be around for the end of this trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've considered that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We proceed, representing your estate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've made provisions in my will for some charities. Miguel will need a lawyer. I know it's not your area...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a good probate lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. (a beat) Do you like opera?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew moves to the stereo, pulling the IV line with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opera?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to hear my favorite aria?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opera?

dialogues.speaker: SUDDENLY, AN ARIA BY MARIA CALLAS FILLS THE ROOM --
dialogues.text: startling Joe with its VOLUME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over the MUSIC) Andrea Chenier, by Giordano. This is Madeleine. She's telling how, during the French revolution, a mob set fire to her house. Her mother died, saving her. "I look... The place that cradled me was burning!" Do you hear the heartache in her voice? Then, here come the strings. Everything changes. The music fills with hope. Madeleine says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew sways through the room to the music, pulling the I at his side. He seems truly free and relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "It was during that sorrow that love came to me! A voice filled with harmony That said... Live still, I am Life!" "I am the god that descends From the heavens to the earth To make of the earth A heaven!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I am Oblivion! I am Glory! I am Love, Love, Love!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll... I told Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Place your left hand on the Bible and raise your right hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Do you swear to tell the truth... DIALOGUE OVERLAP AND DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wyant Wheeler had aggressively recruited me. They were the most prestigious firm in Philadelphia, full of opportunity. And I was impressed by the partners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including Charles Wheeler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Andrew frequently wipes sweat from his forehead with a handkerchief. His voice is hoarse, raspy.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Particularly, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What impressed you about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was... the kind of person I thought I wanted to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of person is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possessed of an encyclopedic knowledge of the law. A razor sharp litigator, a genuine leader, gifted at bringing out the very best in others. An awesome ability to illuminate the most complex of legal concepts to colleagues, courtrooms, the person on the street. (a smile) The kind of person who plays three sets of tennis but doesn't sweat. But underneath the elegant surface, was an adventurous spirit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belinda Conine MAKES A NOTE ABOUT THAT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously, at this time, you weren't sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's possible I was infected with the HIV virus at that time, but I wasn't diagnosed until several years later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't look then, the way you look now?

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: COMPLETELY DIFFERENT (The healthy. pre-AIDS Andrew.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I was thirty pounds heavier. I was athletic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A regular all-American guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you could say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except... you were gay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the years you worked at Wyant Wheeler, did you ever tell Charles Wheeler you were gay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you explain why you didn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't bring your personal life into a law firm. You're not supposed to have a personal life, really. Anyway, I did plan to tell Charles, eventually. But then, this thing happened at the tennis club...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longstreet's interested in the Harrisburg deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm seeing him this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Somebody started telling jokes."

dialogues.text: What do you call a woman who has PMS and ESP at the same time?.

dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bitch who knows everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUGHTER. Andrew keeps his eyes closed, leaning against t wall of the sauna, next to Wheeler, relaxing.

dialogues.text: How does a faggot fake an orgasm?

dialogues.text: Andrew opens one eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spits on your back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles, that's revolting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the men LAUGH, and Wheeler LAUGHS THE HARDEST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did that make you feel?

dialogues.speaker: IMAGE
dialogues.text: it's the sick, thin Andrew with AIDS).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relieved. That I'd never told him I was gay. Very relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON CHARLES WHEELER: shakes his head, a denial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a good lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an excellent lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you an excellent lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love the law. I know the law. I excel at practicing it. It's the only thing I've ever wanted to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you love about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... many things. But I think the thing I love the most, is that every once in a while, not that often, but occasionally... you get to be part of justice being done. It's really quite a thrill when that happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said earlier you aspired to be the kind of person who had "an adventurous spirit." Is that correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you take risks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my work? Yes. Calculated risks. You have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In general. Do you take risks in other areas of your life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not unnecessary ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever been to the Apollo Cinema on Sansom Street?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe cringes a little with discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking Belinda right in the eye) A few times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of movies do they show there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gay movies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gay pornographic movies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do men have sex with each other in that theater?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about you, Mr. Beckett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Have you ever had sex with someone in that theater?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Robert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew.
