dialogues.text: Andrew steps into the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert laughs, closing the door of the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we'll figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE COURTROOM, (INT./DAY)
dialogues.text: Joe sits with a stone-sober expression: this isn't easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When? Approximately what year did this event take place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it was 1984, 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you aware in 1984 or 1985 that there was a fatal disease out there, called AIDS, and that you could contract it through sexual activity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's impossible to know exactly when or how I was infected with HIV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you were having anonymous sex in porno theaters in 1984 and 1985?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That happened once. People weren't talking about AIDS then, the way we are now. Or safe sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd heard of AIDS in 1984, 85?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd heard of something. The gay plague, gay cancer, but... we didn't know how you could get it, or that it could kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT ON ANDREW -- losing strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sounds far away) Do you need a break?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While you were employed at Wyant Wheeler, you did everything you could to make sure no one knew you were an active homosexual, correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is not correct. I never lied about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you keep a picture of your lover on your desk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do other lawyers at the firm keep pictures of their spouses or fiances on their desks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some do. I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a homosexual, one is often forced to conceal one's sexuality, is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In some situations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it true you have spent your life pretending to be something you're not, so much so that the art of concealment and dishonesty has become second nature to you?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll withdraw it. Mr. Beckett? Were you living with Miguel Alvarez in 1984 or 1985 when you had your anonymous sexual encounter in the porn theater?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON MIGUEL, sitting next to Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could have infected him, isn't that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel has not been infected. As I said, we weren't aware of AIDS, then, or how it is spread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew wipes sweat from his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've testified the lesions on your face were visible to the people you worked with, correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's your contention, that when the partners were made aware of the lesions, they jumped to the conclusion you had AIDS and fired you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any lesions on your face at this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One. Here, in front of my ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ASSISTANT hands Conine a shaving mirror. She holds it before Andrew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remembering you are under oath, answering truthfully, can you see the lesion on your face, in this mirror, three feet away? Answering truthfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew looks in the mirror: the lesion is NOT very visibl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the time I was fired, there were four lesions on my face, much bigger...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Answer the question, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I can't really see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew rubs his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (far away) This would be a good time to break for the day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (far away) Your Honor? May I have ten minutes in re-direct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (far away) Beckett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew finds the Judge looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you go on for ten minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe JUMPS UP from the plaintiff's table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only need five! (to Belinda, reaching for the mirror) May I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe approaches Andrew, with the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any lesions on any part of your body, at this time, that resemble the lesions that were on your face at the time you were fired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. On my torso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it please the court, I'd like to ask Mr. Beckett to remove his shirt, so that the jury can have an accurate idea of what we're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We object, Your Honor. It would unfairly influence the jury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, if Mr. Beckett was forced by his illness to use a wheelchair, would the defense ask him to park it outside? We're talking about AIDS, we're talking about lesions. Let's see what we're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a moment, then) I'll allow it. Would you mind removing your shirt, Mr. Beckett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The COURTROOM TURNS SILENT. Andrew removes his suit jacket. He's weak, so the smalles gesture requires effort. ANGLE ON BOB SEIDMAN -- WATCHING. Andrew undoes his tie. ANGLE ON THE MARINE JUROR -- WATCHING. Andrew unbuttons his collar buttons, working his way down ANGLE ON SARAH BECKETT -- WATCHING. Andrew stands, pulling his shirttails out of his trousers ANGLE ON CHARLES WHEELER -- WATCHING. Andrew removes his shirt -- THERE ARE PURPLE BLOTCHES SPLAYED ACROSS HIS CHEST AND ABDOMEN AND ARMS. The SCHOOLTEACHER JUROR GASPS. Sarah Beckett is silently crying. The LESBIAN JUROR closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you see the lesions on your chest in this mirror?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: COURTHOUSE CORRIDOR, ACTIVITY, (INT./DAY)
dialogues.text: Charles Wheeler strides down the corridor, flanked by Kenton, Killcoyne and Belinda, discussing strategy. Bob Seidman steps to Wheeler's side, keeping pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've discovered something interesting, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Belinda) ... keep them from that area, on grounds of relevancy. (to Seidman) What, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No matter how hard I try, I can't lose a file in my computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOW he's got EVERYONE'S attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The system automatically makes a backup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belinda holds up both hands, interrupting with:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I should hear this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks away, giving a glance over her shoulder as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can erase the backup... (a challenge to Wheeler) But why would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (venomous) What's the point, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calm) Very interesting, Bob. Let's make a note of that. Andy didn't lose the complaint in his computer. He never put it in. He lied about that, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weary) Charles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you feel differently, Bob, you should say so, when you're called to the stand. After all, this isn't a conspiracy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheeler and the gang moves on, leaving Seidman alone in t high-ceilinged corridor. Belinda hesitates, before re-grouping with Wheeler and th rest, casting a curious glance toward Bob Seidman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you recruit Andrew Beckett to your firm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew uses all his strength to concentrate. Charles Wheeler speaks with great sincerity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're the owner of a major league ball club, you recruit the hot rookie. And Andy was tremendously promising as a young attorney. That's why we went after him, that's why we hired him, and that's why we stuck with him, year after year... waiting for the promise to be fulfilled. But it never was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kept giving him another chance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course we did. When you've groomed someone they way we groomed Andy, nurturing him, lavishing all kinds of special treatment on him... you've made quite an investment. We were waiting for his promise to kick in, and deliver. But, ultimately, we could no longer ignore the gap between the promise and the reality... This is one of the saddest times in my life. To sit in this court, testifying to Andy's ultimate failure to make the grade. To discover that he is one of those people who wants to benefit by the system, but doesn't want to play by the system's rules. To think you know someone, only to find out... you don't know them at all. It's heartbreaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. That's all for now, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Miller?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe rises. Adjusts his jacket. Wheeler waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very gentle) Explain to me, if you can, Mr. Wheeler, explain this to me like I'm a ten year-old. This trial is not about a disease, is that what you're saying? Not about your understandable, if unfounded, fear of catching AIDS through casual contact with someone who has it? You're saying, this trial is about Andrew Beckett's character. Am I getting this right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, character. To the extent that it affects a person's ability to do a great job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew looks away -- face shiny with sweat, breathing difficult. He takes in the rest of the court, while Wheeler's words THROB THROUGH THE AIR...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy worked when he wanted to work, telling us what he thought we needed to know about his lifestyle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDREW'S POV -- ON RACHEL, sitting among the spectators. begins speaking, her WORDS OVERLAPPING Wheeler's (we shou the feeling she's giving her testimony).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mind covering for Andy, but I did wonder... when was he planning to deal with his problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew blinks... what's going on? Looking back to the court: Joe presses in on Wheeler. Everything seems normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes it seems like society is run by these kinds of people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People who want to bend the rules...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDREW'S POV -- KENNETH KILLCOYNE at the defense table:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to be a leader in this society, you have to make certain sacrifices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheeler keeps speaking:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... to suit their personal desires, and the rest of us have to live with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to make a decision: is this guy partner material?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who makes the rules, Mr. Wheeler? You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I did see the lesions. I suspected he was sick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON ANDREW: closing his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The everyday, common person with decent values...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems like he wasn't willing to face the reality of his situation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew slowly rises, the VOICES GETTING LOUDER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't tell the others, I was afraid to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... But now, we're standing up for ourselves...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... But we shouldn't have fired him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It's time to get this society back on track!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew OPENS HIS EYES... WE SWITCH TO HIS POV: The Judge, the Jury -- everyone silent, looking concerned ANDREW'S POV of the courtroom floor. Andrew falls into his own POV SHOT. In slow motion. He lies on the floor, looking up. ANDREW'S POV -- Joe steps over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you call an ambulance, please?

dialogues.speaker: A CRISIS IN A HOSPITAL ROOM, (INT./DAY)
dialogues.text: working frenetically, trying to intubate Andrew, who IS HAVING SERIOUS TROUBLE BREATHING, his body HEAVING. The tube they're trying to put in place seems to be making matters worse. Miguel stands to the side, furious:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's making it worse. Take it out. Take it out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Gillman RUSHES into the room, in street clothes, obviously having answered an emergency call. She tries assessing the situation, just as the tube is removed and Andrew GASPS for breath. A NURSE places an oxygen mask ov Andrew's face and he drinks in the air. His eyes are wide open with fear, sweat covering his face.

dialogues.speaker: PHILADELPHIA CITY HALL, A BUSINESS DAY, (EXT./DAY)
dialogues.text: TITLE: "Two weeks later."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he was "mediocre," why did they gave him this major assignment three weeks before they fired him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were testing him.

dialogues.speaker: JURORS SITTING AROUND A LONG TABLE IN A ROOM WITH TALL,
dialogues.text: grimy windows (INT./DAY) ... TITLE: "Jury deliberations."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wanted to see if he'd rise to the challenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An American flag hangs on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wanted to give him a final chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd still love to know what happened to that missing file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't we all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask the computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say he wasn't competent. But, you heard him on the stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sounded pretty smart to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would they fire him? Why not a medical leave, or...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They freaked out over the AIDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hate homosexuals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not against the law to disapprove of homosexuals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is against the law to fire someone for having AIDS. That's why we're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the foreman. You haven't said anything. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON -- THE MARINE, sitting at the head of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're saying he wasn't a good lawyer. He was mediocre. And the fact that they gave him the most important lawsuit they'd ever had, for one of their most important clients... they say that doesn't prove anything, because that was just a test. What did they call it? A carrot. To see if he'd rise to the occasion... Okay... Say I've got to send a pilot into enemy territory, and he's gonna be flying a plane that cost 350 million dollars... Who am I going to put into that plane? A rookie who can't cut the grade, because I want to see if he'll rise to the challenge? Or am I going to give that assignment to my best pilot, my most experienced, my sharpest, my top gun... The very best I've got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could somebody please explain that to me... like I'm a six year old?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Members of the jury, have you reached a verdict?

dialogues.speaker: THE COURTROOM
dialogues.text: Joe is utterly cool. Sitting beside Andrew's empty chair. Among the spectators, Andrew's siblings, Jill, Matt, Rand his parents, Bud and Sarah... Rachel, Anthea and Miguel's sister Maria. The Marine rises to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have, Your Honor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles Wheeler looks the Marine in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find for the plaintiff, Andrew Beckett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe smiles, just barely, remaining calm. Charles Wheeler whispers to Belinda Conine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you awarded any damages?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we have, Your Honor. (referring to a list) For back pay and loss of benefits ... one hundred fortythree thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe shakes his head, disappointed, writing down the amoun Wheeler and his crew SMILE -- THIS IS THEIR VICTORY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For damages related to mental anguish and humiliation... we give no award.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is extremely disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And punitive damages we award... Four million, eight hundred and eighty two thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe throws his pen over his shoulder. COURTROOM BURSTS INTO AN UPROAR. Andrew's supporters, Joe's colleagues from his office rus forward, pounding him on the back. Andrew's family member hug each other...

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR DOORS OPENING... JOE STEPPING INTO THE CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: a hospital (INT./NIGHT), carrying two shopping bags from Famous 4th Street deli... Joe moves down the corridor, looking for a particular roo Dr. Gillman stands outside a hospital room, talking in a voice to Bud and Sarah Beckett. As Joe passes them, entering Andrew's room, he hears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... if he comes out of the hospital this time, you mustn't expect him to be like he was before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe steps into... ANDREW'S HOSPITAL ROOM (INT./NIGHT) ... A hand-painted banner is strung over Andrew's bed: "Victory." OPERA MUSIC plays on a portable CD player. ANDREW lies in hospital bed, with a pressurized oxygen mask on his face. JILL sits on the edge of Andrew's bed, holding his hand, smiling, speaking to Andrew in low tones. With his free hand, Andrew gently strokes Jill's forearm. (Andrew has a amazing assortment of tubes and IVs running into various parts of his body.) Andrew's brothers MATT and RANDY are sipping beers with R JIM, MIGUEL, Miguel's sister MARIA, Bruno and Chandra, wh Matt does a dramatic re-creation of the Marine Juror rend the judgment. Matt's audience is loving it. As Joe comes into the room, Jill rises to take the shoppi from him. Joe exchanges nods and greetings with the other People KEEP THEIR VOICES LOW, but there's a certain energ happiness evident in the room. ON ANDREW: Watching his friends and relatives with sparkl eyes and a weak, but grateful and peaceful smile. ON JOE: Glancing across the room, catching Andrew's look. Andrew smiles at Joe and pats his hospital bed, indicatin wants Joe to sit there. Joe crosses the room, sits on the edge of the bed. With some difficulty, Andrew removes his oxygen mask. His voice is raspy, weak:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you call a thousand lawyers chained together at the bottom of the ocean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent work, Joe. I thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was good working with you, Andrew. You're welcome. (sees the oxygen mask) Hey. Shouldn't you put that thing back on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew begins fitting the mask back in place, but his han weak. Joe helps adjust the straps behind Andrew's ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better get home. Lisa and I are having some friends over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muffled by the mask) Sure thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you, Beckett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew nods, weakly. But he's still smiling and his eyes are dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through mask) Thanks for coming by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet. We'll see you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe heads for the door, meeting Miguel there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Miguel) He's looking good. I wouldn't be surprised if he gets out of here soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just want to get him home. Thanks for stopping by, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel puts his arms around Joe and hugs him. Joe slaps Miguel's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe leaves. Miguel begins circulating among the "guests," saying:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's tired. He ought to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: JOE STEPPING INTO THE HOSPITAL ELEVATOR, (INT./NIGHT)
dialogues.text: saying to a GROUP OF DOCTORS and NURSES:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you call a thousand lawyers chained together at the bottom of the ocean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors close.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW'S HOSPITAL ROOM...
dialogues.text: Matt gives Andrew's hand a squeeze, before leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night, Andy. See you tomorrow, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rev. Jim pats Andrew's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God bless you, Andy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud Beckett kisses Andrew on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, son. Get some rest, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah Beckett is strong, kissing Andrew on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight angel, my sweet boy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy Beckett loses control of his emotions as he bends t his brother. He begins to sob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew puts his weak arms, with the IV lines connected, around his brother Randy, to comfort him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through mask) I'm okay, bro. I'll see you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill hugs Andrew, giving Miguel a kiss as she leaves the Maria waves goodnight from the doorway, closing the door. Miguel sits on the edge of the bed, kicking off his shoes Miguel stretches onto the bed next to Andrew, picks up th remote control, and TURNS ON THE TV. Andrew pulls aside the oxygen mask, to say:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ready...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready for what, baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you're ready for "Studs," because that's what's on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew replaces the oxygen mask. They lie next to each other, watching television.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR
dialogues.text: From inside the house: the phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: JOE AND LISA'S DARK BEDROOM, QUIET, (INT./NIGHT)
dialogues.text: Lisa is sitting up in bed, having answered the phone. Joe is just waking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Joe) It's Miguel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sits bolt upright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miguel?

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR
dialogues.text: A TAXI ARRIVES and an elegant, well-dressed older COUPLE step out.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL OPENS THE DOOR OF THE LOFT, FINDING MIGUEL'S FAMIL
dialogues.text: on the other side: very dignified, handsome people who ha just arrived from Spain. They enter the apartment, where. A wake is in progress. Lots of food. People sharing stori about Andrew. Some people laughing. one or two softly cry as they hug each other. Someone has set up a "memento" table, with pictures of An at various stages of his life, and things that meant some to him, like programs from the opera, a ballcap, photos o favorite cat, etc. THEME MUSIC PLAYS, but we hear BITS OF DIALOGUE under the music ("You're Miguel's parents?" "Do you remember when Andy..." "I went to college with Andy..." etc.) Bud Beckett sits alone, very quiet. Miguel leads his parents over to Bud. Bud looks up, rises extending his hand to MIGUEL'S DAD. Miguel's father shake head in sadness, reaches for Bud and pulls him into his a an embrace.

dialogues.speaker: SOMETHING...
dialogues.text: CAMERA ZEROS IN ON THE TV SET, across the room, where BLA WHITE IMAGES ARE FLICKERING, ignored by everyone... AS CAMERA GETS CLOSER TO THE TV, it becomes apparent that images are BLACK AND WHITE HOME MOVIES, converted to vide THE HOME MOVIES FEATURE a bright-eyed LITTLE BOY... Andrew... Riding a bike with training wheels... Swinging wildly at a wiffle ball...

dialogues.speaker: AS CAMERA TRACKS INTO THE TV, PARTY SOUNDS AND THEME MUSI
dialogues.text: FADES... People are still talking, still laughing, still crying, but we CAN'T HEAR THEM ANY LONGER. Instead... We hear only the SOUNDTRACK from the HOME MOVIES... Andrew SHOUTING GLEEFULLY as he chases a new puppy... Andrew SQUEALING as he jumps into a tiny swimming pool... Andrew on a swing, going higher and higher... And laughing. FADE TO BLACK. ROLL END CREDITS. May we never find space so vast,  planets so cold, heart  and mind so empty  that we cannot fill them  with love and warmth...
